NV: This is Melanocytic nevi. Melanocytic nevi are caused by benign proliferations of skin cells called melanocytes. These skin cells produce melanin, which is the pigment responsible for the color of the skin. Normally, melanocytes are distributed evenly throughout the basal layer of the epidermis, which is the outermost layer of the skin. With moles, there is an increase in the number of melanocytes that accumulate in a small area, forming a cluster of cells that causes a darker spot on the skin. Melanocytic nevi can be classified as congenital or acquired. Congenital melanocytic nevi are typically present at birth or may appear within the first few months of life. On the other hand, acquired nevi appear throughout life due to predisposing factors like familial tendency, sun exposure, and skin type, with higher nevus counts seen in individuals with lighter skin tones.

This is Melanocytic nevi. Melanocytic nevi can have different appearances based on their type, location, and the individual’s skin tone. Most congenital nevi are small (i.e., diameter less than 1.5 centimeters [cm]) or medium-sized (i.e., diameter between 1.5 cm and 20 cm). However, they can sometimes measure greater than 20 cm in diameter and these are known as large, or giant, moles. Their color ranges from tan to black or blueish, and the borders are often irregular. One of the characteristic features of congenital nevi is that they usually have hair growing from them.  Acquired nevi, on the other hand, typically appear as brown, flat spots that may become raised over time and tend to be smaller than 6 millimeters in diameter (i.e., the size of a pencil eraser). They are usually symmetrical, with even borders, and consist of one single color. Acquired nevi are more common in sun-exposed areas, such as the trunk, arms, and lower legs, but they can appear anywhere on the body. Some nevi have unique characteristics and are referred to by their names. For example, Sutton nevus is a mole surrounded by a round or oval halo that is lighter in color than the rest of the skin. The Spitz nevus is a pink, red, or brown mole that has a dome shape and is most commonly found in the face and legs. Another example is blue nevus, a characteristic mole that has a blue color due to the location of melanocytes deep within the dermis.

This is Melanocytic nevi. Melanocytic nevi are diagnosed based on the examination of the skin. Trained clinicians may use a magnifying tool called a dermatoscope to help detect features that are not visible to the naked eye. This can assist in the clinical diagnosis and help distinguish common nevi from atypical nevi, as well as malignant lesions like melanoma. Some dermatologists may also photograph certain nevi to monitor for changes over time if the diagnosis is unclear. Individuals who have many moles or who have a family history of melanoma may be recommended to perform self-skin examinations regularly to spot any changes within existing moles or the development of new lesions. A good way to check for suspicious nevi is to use the ABCDE rule. ABCDE stands for Asymmetry, Border irregularities, Color heterogeneity, Diameter over 6 millimeters, and Evolution, which refers to changes in size, color, or shape over time. The presence of one or more of these features indicates a higher chance of malignant transformation. For a definitive diagnosis of suspicious nevi, an excisional biopsy may be performed to rule out melanoma.

This is Melanocytic nevi. Most melanocytic nevi remain benign throughout a person’s lifetime and require no treatment other than observation. However, several treatment options can help reduce the appearance of moles or remove them altogether in case of cosmetic concerns. Common treatments include surgical excision and laser therapy. Surgical removal may include shave excision, which involves “shaving” or removing the mole with a sharp blade. This technique is most effective in moles that affect only the epidermis and has the advantage of leaving minimal or no scarring. For deeper lesions, or in cases where there is a higher risk of malignancy, an excisional biopsy may be needed to remove the whole lesion. On the other hand, lasers work by emitting specific wavelengths of light that are absorbed by melanin. Melanin transforms the energy absorbed from the laser into heat that destroys the pigment in the skin, thereby decreasing the appearance of the mole. Some of the most effective ways to prevent the development of nevi include decreasing exposure to UV rays by wearing sun-protective clothing, using broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher; and avoiding artificial UV rays like tanning beds. Studies have shown these measures are especially effective during childhood and adolescence, which is when most melanocytic nevi are formed.

AKIEC: What is this skin condition?

This is Actinic keratosis. Actinic keratosis is a pre-cancerous skin lesion on the skin. They are usually rough, scaly patches that form on the areas that receive extensive sun exposure: the face, lips, ears, backs of the hands, forearms, scalp, or neck. These growths develop slowly and don’t have any signs or symptoms other than their appearance. A small percentage of actinic keratoses can eventually become skin cancer.
Is this skin condition a form of skin cancer?

This is Actinic keratosis. These growths are “pre-cancerous,” meaning they are not cancer, but they may develop into skin cancer. If an actinic keratosis is left untreated it can turn into a squamous cell carcinoma. This happens in only 5 to 10 percent of cases of actinic keratoses, but it’s still wise to have the spot looked at by a board-certified dermatologist.
What are the symptoms of this skin condition?

This is Actinic keratosis. These growths are not painful and are not overly disfiguring because they remain small. These are the signs:
1) The rough, scaly, dry patch of skin
2) Usually less than 1 inch in diameter
3) Flat to slightly raised patch or bump atop the skin
4) Sometimes can be hard and wart-like
5) Color may be pink, red, or brown
6) May itch or burn when brushed
What causes this skin condition to form?
This is Actinic keratosis. Actinic keratoses develop as the skin’s response to frequent or intense exposure to ultraviolet radiation from the sun or tanning beds
Who is most prone to developing this skin condition?

This is Actinic keratosis. Actinic keratoses develop due to exposure to UV radiation. But not everyone’s skin reacts the same way; one person may develop actinic keratosis, while another with the same exposure shows no signs. They are anything but rare, with estimates placing the number of Americans with one or more actinic keratosis at 58 million. 

These are certain risk factors that make a person more likely to develop an actinic keratosis:

You are over age 40
Live in a sunny locale
Have a history of sunburns
Have red or blond hair
Have blue or light-colored eyes
Tend to freckle or burn when exposed to sunlight
Have a personal history of actinic keratoses or skin cancer
Have a weak immune system due to chemotherapy, AIDS, or other causes
How is this skin condition diagnosed?

This is Actinic keratosis. These are not complicated diagnoses. Your dermatologist will likely be able to determine if that lesion on your skin is an actinic keratosis with a simple examination. If there is any doubt, your dermatologist may use a curette, a small spoon-shaped tool, to scrape the lesion for a biopsy. Often, regardless of the result of the biopsy, this action can remove the entire actinic keratosis. 

Once a diagnosis has been made, it’s likely your dermatologist will recommend treatment, such as freezing the lesion with liquid nitrogen. If treated, virtually all actinic keratoses can be cleared up or removed before they turn into squamous cell carcinoma.
How is this skin condition treated?

This is Actinic keratosis. Because actinic keratoses may develop into cancer, it’s a good idea to remove them as a precaution. Here are the typical methods:
        
        Medications -- Fluorouracil cream, Imiquimod cream, Ingenol mebutate gel, Diclofenac gel

Cryotherapy -- Actinic keratoses can be removed by freezing the growth with liquid nitrogen. This causes the lesion to crust and peel off. This takes just a few minutes.

Curettage -- A small scoop-shaped blade, known as a curet, is used to scrape off the damaged cells. Using the curet may complete the procedure, or we may also use electrosurgery, where an electric current destroys the affected tissue and closes off the blood vessels.
Can this skin condition Heal on its Own?

This is Actinic keratosis. Sometimes, an actinic keratosis will go away spontaneously. However, because these growths are related to sun exposure and sun damage that rises to the epidermis from deeper layers of the skin, it is very likely that new AK lesions will sprout up over time. It is impossible to determine which AKs will develop into skin cancer and which will remain benign. As a precaution, your doctor may advise you to remove these growths before they turn into skin cancer.
Does this skin condition Spread?

This is Actinic keratosis. Actinic keratoses can be somewhat unpredictable. Usually, these pre-cancerous growths remain localized. They may go away and then new ones return. However, if an AK lesion becomes squamous cell carcinoma, which can occur, there is a risk that the cancerous cells will spread to nearby lymph nodes. A consultation with a board-certified dermatologist who specializes in skin cancer diagnosis and treatment is warranted for any person who displays the signs of actinic keratosis.
How Long Does this skin condition Take to Develop?

This is Actinic keratosis. Actinic keratosis lesions are growths that can occur many years after excessive sun exposure has caused DNA damage in the skin cells. This condition is usually seen in middle-aged adults, revealing the massive amount of time between original sun exposure and the development of tissue irregularities. That said, once you have an AK lesion, or many, these growths may transform into skin cancer within a three-year period. It is critical that you continue to perform skin cancer checks on a monthly basis so that you can be very familiar with your skin in general and, specifically, notice when a spot or growth changes.
BKL: This is Benign keratosis. Benign keratosis is a non-cancerous growth that forms on the skin, usually appearing as a small, raised, rough patch. These growths are made of keratin, a protein that helps protect the skin. While benign, they can be unsightly and may become irritated or inflamed.

This is Benign keratosis. The exact cause of benign keratosis is not fully understood, but it is believed to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Sun exposure, aging, and certain genetic predispositions can increase the likelihood of developing these growths.
What are the symptoms of this skin condition?

This is Benign keratosis. Symptoms of benign keratosis typically include small, raised, and often scaly or crusty spots that may be tan, brown, or black in color. They can vary in size and may feel rough to the touch. While usually painless, they can sometimes become itchy or irritated.
How can you differentiate this skin condition from skin cancer?

This is Benign keratosis. Benign keratosis usually appears as well-defined, raised, and rough patches that may have a wart-like appearance. Skin cancer, on the other hand, may present as irregular, asymmetrical growths that change in size, color, and shape over time. It is important to have any suspicious skin growth evaluated by a dermatologist for accurate diagnosis.
What are the treatment options for this skin condition?

This is Benign keratosis. Treatment for benign keratosis is typically not necessary unless it becomes bothersome or causes discomfort. Options include cryotherapy (freezing the growth), laser therapy, or topical treatments such as creams that help remove the keratosis. Dermatologists can advise on the most suitable treatment based on the size, location, and number of growths.
Are these skin conditions growths dangerous?

This is Benign keratosis. No, benign keratosis growths are non-cancerous and do not pose a health risk. However, they can sometimes be mistaken for skin cancer, so it is important to have any new or changing skin growths checked by a healthcare professional to ensure proper diagnosis.
Can this skin condition become malignant?

This is Benign keratosis. Benign keratosis itself does not transform into skin cancer. However, there are different types of skin growths, and while benign keratosis is non-cancerous, other types of skin lesions may have a risk of developing into cancer. A dermatologist can help differentiate between them.
How can I prevent this skin condition?

This is Benign keratosis. While it is not always possible to prevent benign keratosis, minimizing sun exposure, wearing sunscreen, and protecting the skin from harmful UV rays can reduce the risk of developing various types of skin growths. Regular skin checks are also recommended to monitor any changes.
DF: What is this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibroma is a common, benign skin growth that typically appears as a small, firm, raised bump on the skin. It is usually brown or tan in color and may have a slightly rough texture. Dermatofibromas are generally harmless and are more commonly found on the legs, arms, or upper body.
What causes this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. The exact cause of dermatofibroma is not fully understood, but it is believed to develop from an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in response to an injury or skin irritation. They can form after a minor trauma, such as a bug bite, a cut, or other skin injuries.
What are the symptoms of this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibromas typically present as small, firm nodules that may be brown, tan, or slightly darker in color. They are often asymptomatic but can be itchy or tender when touched. If squeezed, they may exhibit a dimple sign, where the center of the lesion appears to be pushed inward.
How can I differentiate this skin condition from other skin growths?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibromas are usually distinguishable from other skin growths by their appearance and texture. They are firm, raised, and often have a brown or tan color. The dimple sign, where pressing the lesion causes the center to sink, is a key feature. Unlike moles or other growths, dermatofibromas do not typically grow in size or change rapidly.
Is this skin condition cancerous?

This is Dermatofibroma. No, dermatofibroma is a non-cancerous (benign) skin growth and is generally not a cause for concern. While it can be unsightly or occasionally tender, it does not pose any health risks. However, if there is any change in size, color, or symptoms, it is wise to have it evaluated by a dermatologist.
What are the treatment options for this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. Treatment for dermatofibroma is typically not necessary unless it becomes painful, bothersome, or if the individual desires its removal for cosmetic reasons. If treatment is desired, options include excision (surgical removal), laser treatment, or cryotherapy (freezing). A dermatologist can help determine the best treatment method.
Can this skin condition go away on its own?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibromas usually do not go away on their own and may persist for many years. While some may shrink or become less noticeable over time, most remain stable. If a dermatofibroma becomes painful or changes, seeking medical advice is recommended.
How can I prevent this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. There is no known way to prevent dermatofibroma as their formation is often related to minor skin trauma or irritation. Protecting the skin from injuries and practicing good skincare can help reduce the risk of developing other types of skin lesions, though it is not a guarantee against dermatofibromas.
Are these skin condition more common in certain people?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibromas are more commonly found in adults and are slightly more prevalent in women than men. They often appear between the ages of 20 and 40, but can occur at any age. A history of minor skin trauma or skin irritation can also increase the likelihood of developing dermatofibromas.
What is the prognosis for this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. The prognosis for dermatofibroma is excellent as they are benign growths that do not turn cancerous. They are typically harmless and only require treatment if they become painful or are cosmetically undesirable. Recurrence after removal is rare but can occur.
What Is this skin condition?
This is Dermatofibroma. A dermatofibroma is a harmless, nodular lesion that sits in the deeper layers of the skin. It is a firm bump and can range in colour from pink to brown.
Is this skin condition Dangerous?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibromas are not dangerous or cancerous. They are benign nodules that sit under the skin, and it is not necessary to treat them. However, you may find the lesion annoying or unsightly and may choose to have it removed for this reason.
What Is the 'Pinch Test' regarding that skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibromas can have a dimple or depression when pinched. As part of your clinical examination, your clinician may carry out this 'pinch test' to determine if your lesion is a dermatofibroma. At the Altruderm clinic, we will also carry out a dermatoscopic examination where the doctor assesses the lesion using magnification.
Is a Surgical Excision the Best Method of Removal for this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. If you decide that you would like to have your dermatofibroma removed then surgical excision, with adequate margins, is the best method of removal. This ensures that the dermatofibroma is unlikely to recur.
What Type of Anaesthetic Is Used for This Procedure of removal of this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. Dermatofibroma removal is a minor surgical procedure carried out under local anaesthetic. The dermatofibroma is numbed by injection so you will not feel any pain when the lesion is removed. You will be awake and the doctor will check with you to ensure you do not feel any pain. As this procedure is carried out using local anaesthetic you will be able to return to your normal duties straight away, but avoiding any strenuous exercise.
What Is the Recommended Aftercare Following a the removal of this skin condition?

This is Dermatofibroma. Following your procedure the area will have a dressing which should remain on and dry for 2 days. After this you should remove the dressing. If your sutures are dissolving, they will disappear over time. If your sutures are non-dissolving you will return to the clinic to have them removed. In either case, you are welcome to attend the clinic for a wound check at any time. The type of suture chosen for your procedure will depend on where the dermatofibroma is on the body.
VASC: What is this skin condition?

This is vascular lesion. A vascular lesion is an abnormal growth or malformation of blood vessels in the skin or underlying tissues. These can include conditions like hemangiomas, varicose veins, spider veins, and port-wine stains. Vascular lesions can be congenital or develop over time due to various factors, including sun exposure or aging.
What causes this skin condition?

This is vascular lesion. Vascular lesions are typically caused by the abnormal development or growth of blood vessels. They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired due to factors like trauma, hormonal changes, sun exposure, or underlying medical conditions. In some cases, the exact cause is unknown.
What are the types of this skin condition?

This is vascular lesion. Common types of vascular lesions include:
1. **Hemangiomas**: Red or purple raised growths often seen in infants.
2. **Spider veins (telangiectasias)**: Small, thin, red, or blue vessels near the skin’s surface.
3. **Varicose veins**: Enlarged, twisted veins that often appear on the legs.
4. **Port-wine stains**: Red or purple birthmarks caused by abnormal blood vessels.
5. **Venous malformations**: Larger lesions involving deep veins, often present at birth.
What are the symptoms of this skin condition?

This is vascular lesion. The symptoms of vascular lesions can vary depending on the type and location. They may include visible, discolored patches or nodules on the skin, pain, swelling, or a feeling of heaviness in the affected area. Some vascular lesions may not cause any symptoms aside from their appearance.
How can you differentiate between this skin condition and other skin conditions?

This is vascular lesion. Differentiating vascular lesions from other skin conditions typically involves evaluating the color, size, and shape of the lesion, as well as any associated symptoms. Vascular lesions often appear red, purple, or blue, and may have a raised or flat surface. A dermatologist may use a dermatoscope or perform a biopsy if needed for diagnosis.
Is this skin condition dangerous?

This is vascular lesion. Most vascular lesions are benign and not dangerous. However, some, especially larger ones or those that affect deeper tissues, can lead to complications like bleeding or discomfort. Certain types, such as port-wine stains, may be associated with other medical conditions that need to be monitored by a healthcare professional.
What are the treatment options for this skin condition?

This is vascular lesion. Treatment options for vascular lesions depend on the type, size, and location of the lesion. Common treatments include:
1. **Laser therapy**: Often used to treat superficial lesions like spider veins and port-wine stains.
2. **Sclerotherapy**: A procedure that involves injecting a solution into veins to close them.
3. **Surgical removal**: For larger, more problematic lesions.
4. **Electrocautery**: Using electrical current to remove or shrink the lesion.
Consulting a dermatologist is important to choose the most appropriate treatment.
Can this skin condition go away on their own?

This is vascular lesion. Some vascular lesions, such as certain types of hemangiomas, may shrink or disappear naturally over time, particularly in infants. However, most vascular lesions, especially those that are more established or deeper, will not go away on their own and may require medical treatment to reduce their appearance or symptoms.
How can I prevent this skin condition?

This is vascular lesion. There is no guaranteed way to prevent vascular lesions, as many are congenital or related to genetic factors. However, protecting the skin from excessive sun exposure, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, and managing conditions that can contribute to vascular issues (e.g., obesity or pregnancy) can help reduce the risk of developing some types of vascular lesions.
What is the prognosis for this skin condition?

This is vascular lesion. The prognosis for vascular lesions is generally good, especially for benign types. Treatments are often effective in reducing or eliminating the appearance of the lesions. However, the success of treatment depends on factors such as the type of lesion, its size, and the chosen method of treatment. Regular follow-ups with a dermatologist are recommended to monitor the condition and address any recurrence.
SCC: What is squamous cell carcinoma?

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a type of skin cancer that arises from squamous cells, which are the thin, flat cells found on the surface of the skin. It is one of the most common types of skin cancer and typically appears as a red, scaly patch, an open sore, or a raised growth with a central depression.
What causes squamous cell carcinoma?

Squamous cell carcinoma is primarily caused by prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun or tanning beds. Other risk factors include a weakened immune system, exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., arsenic), chronic skin inflammation, and a history of previous skin cancers. Genetic predisposition and a fair skin type can also increase the risk.
What are the symptoms of squamous cell carcinoma?

Symptoms of squamous cell carcinoma include a firm, red nodule, a scaly, crusted, or ulcerated lesion, or a flat lesion with a raised border. The affected area may feel sore, tender, or may bleed. SCC commonly appears on sun-exposed areas such as the face, ears, neck, lips, and backs of hands, but it can develop anywhere on the body.
How is squamous cell carcinoma diagnosed?

Squamous cell carcinoma is diagnosed through a physical examination by a dermatologist and confirmed with a skin biopsy. During a biopsy, a small sample of the suspicious tissue is removed and examined under a microscope to check for cancer cells.
What are the treatment options for squamous cell carcinoma?

Treatment for squamous cell carcinoma depends on the size, location, and stage of the cancer. Common treatments include:
1. **Surgical excision**: The removal of the cancerous tissue and a margin of surrounding healthy tissue.
2. **Curettage and electrodessication**: Scraping away the cancer and using electrical current to destroy remaining cancer cells.
3. **Cryotherapy**: Freezing the tumor with liquid nitrogen.
4. **Radiation therapy**: For larger or more difficult-to-treat areas.
5. **Topical medications**: For superficial cases, topical chemotherapy or immune-modulating creams may be used.
Consulting a dermatologist or oncologist is crucial for determining the best treatment plan.
Is squamous cell carcinoma dangerous?

Squamous cell carcinoma is generally considered less dangerous than melanoma, but it can still be serious if left untreated. While most SCCs are localized and can be effectively treated, advanced or neglected cases may spread to other parts of the body (metastasize), which can be life-threatening.
What are the risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma?

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma include prolonged sun exposure, a history of sunburns, fair skin, a weakened immune system (due to conditions like HIV or medications for organ transplants), a history of previous skin cancer, exposure to certain chemicals (e.g., arsenic), and chronic skin conditions like actinic keratosis.
Can squamous cell carcinoma be prevented?

Squamous cell carcinoma can be largely prevented by protecting the skin from UV radiation. This includes wearing sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher, wearing protective clothing, seeking shade, and avoiding tanning beds. Regular skin checks by a dermatologist and self-examinations can help detect any unusual growths early.
What is the prognosis for squamous cell carcinoma?

The prognosis for squamous cell carcinoma is generally very good, especially if detected and treated early. Most cases can be cured with proper treatment. However, the risk of recurrence or metastasis increases with larger or more aggressive tumors. Regular follow-ups with a dermatologist are recommended to monitor for any signs of recurrence.
How can I identify squamous cell carcinoma from other skin growths?

Squamous cell carcinoma can often be distinguished by its firm, red nodule, scaly patches, or an open sore that does not heal. It may appear rough and raised with a central ulceration. If a lesion changes over time, grows, bleeds, or does not heal within a few weeks, it is important to consult a dermatologist for evaluation.
